title: Aussies 'distressed' after company accidentally transforms 20km of rural canal into 'death trap'
text:
One of Australia’s largest private irrigation companies has “unintentionally” transformed kilometres of a supply channel into a “death trap” for native animals. The problem occurred after Murrumbidgee Irrigation engineers upgraded the watercourse by lining its rough concrete walls with black plastic, which is slippery when wet, and impossible for animals to grip onto.

According to locals, the drownings have been centred along a 20km section of canal that runs through farmland in Griffith, a NSW Riverina city commonly referred to as the foodbowl of Australia. One picture supplied to Yahoo News shows the bodies of seven kangaroos floating in one spot, but locals say the problem has been ongoing for years and they've lost count of the dead.

Responding to questions from Yahoo News, the company has agreed this week to address the problem, but for many residents, a solution can’t come quickly enough. “It’s been pretty awful,” local school bus driver Anita Tovo told Yahoo News.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Despite not having any wildlife training, fishing struggling animals out of the water has largely fallen on her shoulders. She frequently spots kangaroos drowning during her regular route beside a stretch of the Lakeview Branch Canal, and they’re sometimes noticed by the kids riding with her.

“I don’t think I’ve ever gone down the road, morning or afternoon, and not seen a drowned kangaroo, all through the summer season,” she told Yahoo News.

Earlier this month, she photographed the bodies of seven kangaroos, floating dead in the water.

On October 13, a Griffith school bus driver saw seven kangaroos dead in the canal. Source: Supplied

The Lakeview Branch Canal can be seen running through the centre of this satellite image. Source: Google Earth

On a separate occasion last year, a small kangaroo managed to scramble out of the water. A picture taken by Anita shows the animal staring back at the camera through thick foliage following its escape. But because the channel is protected by a high fence with few openings, it fell in again and drowned three days later.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“It was floating in the water. I was just so frustrated, I wished I’d just got bolt cutters and mutilated the fence,” she said.

Rescue volunteer struggles to respond to channel incidents

NSW’s largest wildlife rescue service, WIRES, has a small presence in the sprawling Griffith area. The closest rescue volunteer to the channel, Amanda McCloy, works as a busy nurse over 50km away.

“By the time someone finds a kangaroo during the day at first light, it's probably been in there for hours, and by the time I'd get out there, it's too late, they're drowned,” she told Yahoo.

She describes the situation created by the plastic lining as "shocking". Only on one occasion has she been able to fish a young kangaroo out of thick silt at the bottom of a canal when the water was low.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“There’s no point having plastic in there, keeping the water clean, if animals are dying in there, and animals are rotting in there,” she said.

This kangaroo managed to scramble out of the canal but died days later after falling in again. Source: Supplied

This is the only kangaroo that WIRES volunteer Amanda McCloy has been able to rescue from the channel. Source: WIRES

Irrigation company responds to community concern

After being contacted by Yahoo News, Murrumbidgee Irrigation asserted there are strategic exit points in the fence, and that camera monitoring and regular inspections help the company “respond quickly to any incidents”.

But it also acknowledged the “distressing reports of animals becoming trapped” in its channels from the community.

“We understand that these incidents are upsetting and empathise with those who have witnessed or been affected by them. It is concerning whenever any animal is injured, regardless of the circumstances,” it said in an email.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

It confirmed 113 kilometres of supply channels had been lined to both improve water delivery and reduce seepage. “While these upgrades are essential for ensuring efficient and sustainable water use, we acknowledge that they can unintentionally impact local wildlife,” it said.

Anita Tovo said kangaroos can be seen drowned throughout the summer. On Tuesday, she spoke to Yahoo News and took this image of one dead in the canal. Source: Supplied

Murrumbidgee Irrigation makes commitment after canal drownings

Responding to Yahoo News about the issue, Murrumbidgee Irrigation committed to improving its infrastructure to improve wildlife safety. It also agreed to work with WIRES head office to combat the problem.

WIRES CEO Leanne Taylor said the drowning deaths have been “distressing” for both members of the public and its volunteers.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“WIRES welcomes an immediate collaboration with Murrumbidgee Irrigation and other Emergency Services agencies to assist with the rescuing and release of native wildlife trapped in this stretch of channel,” she said.

“Further proactive measures by Murrumbidgee Irrigation is greatly appreciated to help prevent the suffering being caused to these poor animals.”

Love Australia's weird and wonderful environment? 🐊🦘😳 Get our new newsletter showcasing the week’s best stories.

title: ‘Concerning’ claim in Rebel’s lawsuit
text:
Rebel Wilson’s honesty has been thrown into question in court after an actor who starred in her troubled film The Deb launched a lawsuit against the Aussie star.

Actor Charlotte MacInnes’ defamation case in the NSW registry of the Federal Court concerns social media posts made by Ms Wilson.

The posts are said to imply that Ms MacInnes lied when denying she made a complaint about one of the film’s producers, Amanda Ghost, allegedly sexually harassing her or engaging in other unacceptable behaviour that made her feel uncomfortable, documents released by the court and seen by NewsWire claim.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The posts also allegedly imply that Ms MacInnes “changed her story” about the alleged complaint in return for a lead role in another of Ms Ghost’s productions and a record deal.

The documents claim the imputations are “false and seriously defamatory”, harming Ms MacInnes’ reputation at a critical point in her career.

Ms MacInnes’ lawyer Sue Chrysanthou SC on Friday argued in the NSW Federal Court that Ms Wilson should not need additional time to file a statement to the court if she was “telling the truth”.

“People telling the truth don’t need to see documents in order to make a statement,” Ms Chrysanthou told the court.

Rebel Wilson is facing legal action over a series of social media posts. Picture: NewsWire / Christian Gilles

Charlotte MacInnes starred in Ms Wilson’s troubled film The Deb. Picture: Supplied.

“We don’t understand why … she would be assisted by text messages to help her remember what happened.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“That’s concerning to us.”

She argued that Ms Wilson must be “very familiar with what she thinks happened”, claiming the Aussie actor had repeatedly aired the allegations in public.

“We’re highly concerned about this notion that (Ms Wilson) would need to see documents in advance,” Ms Chrysanthou said.

“I don’t think there’s any need for delay when it comes to the exchange of evidence.”

Renee Enbom KC, acting for Ms Wilson, rejected the claim.

“People who are giving evidence about events that occurred three years ago often need to be assisted by documents,” Ms Enbom said.

Ms Wilson’s lawyer denied claims that the star continued to ‘attack’ Ms MacInnes after court proceedings were launched. Picture: Araya Doheny/Getty Images.

There was further dispute about when Ms Wilson should be required to file all of her evidence in the case.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Ms Enbom pushed for an extra two months or so from the proposed date in December, telling the court it was not enough time to pull together evidence from about 10 witnesses.

“That is an unbelievable delay in a defamation case,” Ms Chrysanthou hit back.

“Ms Wilson is not busier than … any other litigant in this court.”

Natalie Abbott, Rebel Wilson, Charlotte MacInnes and Stevie Jean at a party to celebrate the launch of The Deb. Picture: Dave Benett/Getty Images for Warner Music

She claimed her client, also an actor, had been “unapologetically defamed”, and Ms Wilson was “clearly not too busy” to keep making claims against Ms MacInnes.

Ms Chrysanthou claimed Ms Wilson had continued to “attack” Ms MacInnes despite the court proceedings; however, Ms Enbom said there was no evidence of this.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“I don’t accept that my client is continuing to attack Ms MacInnes publicly … there’s no evidence of that,” Ms Enbom said.

Justice Elizabeth Raper ultimately ordered Ms Wilson to file her statement by December 10 and the rest of her evidence by February next year before a directions hearing scheduled for February 27.

Ms Enbom said Ms Wilson’s affidavit would be “extensive”.

“Her evidence is not simple and straightforward, it goes back to 2022 … and it deals with numerous issues, not just the sexual harassment.” Ms Enbom said.

She indicated the trial would likely span up to four weeks, prompting Justice Raper to ask “Really?”

Lawyers for Ms MacInnes sent a concerns notice to Ms Wilson in August and launched proceedings on September 22 after Ms Wilson allegedly failed to respond within 28 days.

title: Plane makes emergency landing in Sydney
text:
An international flight from New Zealand has been forced to make an emergency landing at Sydney Airport after a reported mid-air hydraulic failure.

Flight NZ221, departing from Christchurch to Sydney, reported a technical issue mid-air and was forced to make the landing before 9am Friday as a precaution, Air New Zealand chief safety and risk officer Nathan McGraw said in a statement.

“The aircraft landed safely, and our engineering team will now carry out inspections to ensure the aircraft is safe to return to service,” Mr McGraw confirmed.

Flight NZ221, departing from Christchurch to Sydney, reported a technical issue mid-air. Picture: Supplied

It is understood a hydraulic issue on-board was the reason for the emergency landing in Sydney. Picture: Supplied

Passengers were informed mid-flight about the emergency landing via an in-cabin announcement.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Emergency services, including Sydney Airport’s Fire and Rescue crews and ground support vehicles, attended the aircraft as it touched down.

It is understood the plane remained stationary on the tarmac for two hours as engineers assessed the hydraulic issue, before the plane was towed to the gate and passengers allowed to disembark.

The aircraft landed safely after being forced to make the emergency manoeuvre. Picture: Supplied

One passenger on board told The Daily Mail the landing was still “smooth” and everyone was calm on board.

Another said it was confusing at first as no-one knew what was going on.

“When we landed, we had to wait on the plane for about an hour,” the passenger told the outlet.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“There were fire trucks and flashing lights everywhere, which was a bit of an experience. It felt a little unsettling, but everyone stayed patient.

“I just wanted to stand up and move around, but it was fine overall.”

More to come.
